Blog.post: Eu e a Carol. urlLink
Eu com meus pais e meus filhos. urlLink

Ou a volta, como preferir. Resolvi escrever minhas idéias na internet - de novo. Talvez no futuro encontre alguma utilidade para isso, mas no momento é mais pra curtir uma onda. Estou meio feliz. É que a Carol (minha esposa) me deu um gelo por causa de uma diferença de opinião sobre o uso do micro de madrugada. Além disso estou recém operado de uma @#%&¨* de um cisto pilonidal recidivante. Pensei em incluir uma foto do bicho mas acho melhor começar pegando leve.
Garoto-Propaganda urlLink
Bailarina na Varanda urlLink

O Pedro come a quantidade que for oferecida para ele, sem dar sinais de plenitude. Fica bravo se o intervalo entre as colheradas for superior a cinco segundos e tem pequenos tremores quando acaba a refeição.
urlLink Luana abraça Pedro com carinho. urlLink

"Papai! Papai!", gritou Luana ao me ver em casa quando chegou com a Dudi, com quem passara o dia ontem. Pedrinho é o cara mais tranqüilo e simpático: dá risada o tempo todo e -tímido - vira o rosto encabulado... Hoje Luana tem 3 anos e Pedro, 4 meses. Tenho uma família linda e só poderia ser mais feliz se tivesse mais tempo para passar com eles. Ainda bem que Carol é compreensiva, ela sabe que por enquanto nossa sobrevivência depende dos meus plantões. Mas isso pode estar prestes a mudar... Tomara!

People with diabetes mellitus are at risk of developing the vision disorder known as diabetic retinopathy. This condition occurs as a result of damage to the small blood vessels in the retina�the light-sensitive lining at the back of the eye. Symptoms may include blurred central or side vision, or a blind spot in the central vision. Prompt medical treatment can prevent this condition from worsening. urlLink
A cataract is a cloudy area in the lens of the eye. To a person with cataracts, the world appears hazy and out of focus. Cataracts can be successfully treated with surgery. urlLink

Glaucoma occurs when increased pressure within the eye causes harm to the optic nerve, which carries visual information from the eye to the brain. A common symptom is the loss of side, or peripheral, vision. Those at risk of developing glaucoma include African Americans, diabetics, people over age 40, and people with a family history of the disease. If detected and treated in its early stages, glaucoma can be controlled and vision can be saved. urlLink

Macular degeneration is the most common cause of irreversible vision loss in the United States. People with this condition gradually lose their central visionthe part of vision needed for reading and seeing fine details. Such people rarely become completely blind because their side, or peripheral, vision remains intact. urlLink

Diagnosis: Necrotizing Anterior Scleritis (Scleromalacia Perforans) Comment: Thinning of anterior sclera makes dark uveal tissue visible. No signs of inflammation urlLink

Diagnosis: Thyroid Eye Disease, Graves' Disease (#2,1) Comment: Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder characterized by hyperthyroidism, orbitopathy, and pretibial myxedema, not all of which need to be present. The orbital disease shows proptosis, periorbital edema, and eyelid retraction, frequently accompanied by strabismus. urlLink

Diagnosis: Entropion, Involutional Comment: The most common cause of entropion is involutional. There is laxity of the vertical retractors with loss of fixation of the tarsal plate and backward rotation of the eyelid margin. It is seen most often in the lower eyelid. urlLink

Diagnosis: Ectropion, Involutional Comment: This condition results from horizontal laxity of the eyelid, either at lateral canthal tendon or more diffusely along the length of the tarsal plate. urlLink
Diagnosis: Hordeolum of Lid Comment: Painful staphylococcal infection of the Meibomian or Zeis gland urlLink

Diagnosis: Chalazion Comment: This is a focal inflammation of the eyelid caused by obstruction of a meibomian gland. Findings include an elevated nodule near the lid margin, with pain and erythema. urlLink
Diagnosis: Mature Cataract Comment: The cortex of the lens is opacified and the nucleus is brown. A membrane has formed underneath the anterior capsule. urlLink
Diagnosis: Woundrupture with Loss of Intraocular Contents Comment: Blunt trauma after corneal transplant. The hemorrhagic vitreous is visible in the corneal wound, the lens is lost. urlLink

Diagnosis: Iris Prolaps in perforating injury Comment: Iris tissue has prolapsed through a corneal wound. The pupil has peaked toward the prolaps. The eye is inflamed as indicated by the injection of the vessels. urlLink

Diagnosis: Hematocornea (2) Comment: With the passage of time the opacifying blood breakdown products are disappearing first in the periphery. The left side of the iris of this trauma case is covered with white scar tissue.Anterior synechia from 5-10h urlLink
Diagnosis: Foreign Body of Cornea (1) Comment: An iron containing foreign body rests in the cornea and rust is spreading into the surrounding tissue. urlLink
Diagnosis: CL damage with Severe bacterial Keratitis and Immun Ring(5) Comment: Hypopyon urlLink
queimadura por gas lacrimogenio urlLink
queimadura por substancia alcalina urlLink
queimadura por acido urlLink
Diagnosis: Neuroparalytic Corneal Ulcer Comment: With loss of sensitivity the cornea was damaged and infected. Large epithelial defect and infiltrate. urlLink
Diagnosis: Corneal Ulcer, Fungal (1) Comment: Fungal ulcers are indolent and infiltrate the cornea deeply. A hypopyon has developed, the eye is heavily injected. urlLink
Diagnosis: Acanthamoebic Keratitis Comment: Typical are epithelial irregularyties without defects, focal stromal edma, superficial ring-infiltrate, pain urlLink
Diagnosis: Trachoma (2) Comment: Pannus formation at the superior limbus with vessels encroaching upon the cornea. (Stage 2) urlLink
Diagnosis: Luetic Keratitis Parenchymatosa Comment: Cloudy corneal opacities indicate a former inflammation, caused by connatal syphilis urlLink

Diagnosis: Leprosy Granuloma at the Limbus Comment: Consisting of lymphocytes, histiocytes and plasma cells). It is typical for the delayed type of sensitivity reaction to Mycobacterium leprae. urlLink
Diagnosis: Vernal conjunctivitis Comment: Papillary hypertrophy of the tarsal conjunctiva. urlLink
Diagnosis: Hemangioma (Cavernous) of the Conjunctiva Comment: Localized, very dilated conjunctival vessels in a 13-year-old child urlLink
Diagnosis: Malignant Melanoma of Conjunctiva Comment: Pigmented tumor that has spread across the whole palpebral surface. Either arisen from aquired melanosis, a nevus or de novo. urlLink
Diagnosis: Papilloma of the Caruncle Comment: Pedunculated when arising at the caruncle. Vascularized with enlarged feeder vessels. Caused by virus. urlLink
Diagnosis: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of Conjunctiva at the Limbus Comment: With corneal invasion. urlLink
Diagnosis: Hemorrhage in the Conjunctiva, Hyposphagma Comment: This hemorrhage can occur spontaneously or after trauma urlLink
Diagnosis: Conjunctival (Implantation) Cyst Comment: Cyst is filled with liquid. It usually develops after surgery due to inadvertent subconjunctival implantaion of conjunctival tissue. urlLink
Diagnosis: Gonococcal Conjunctivitis Comment: Infection with Neisseria gonorrhea causes a hyper acute conjunctivitis with copious purulent discharge and swelling of the lid. urlLink
Diagnosis: Follicular Conjunctivitis Comment: Lymphoid tissue forms follicles. There is no discharge or hyperemia. Occurs in children from age 4 to adolescence. urlLink
Pterígio avançado urlLink
Diagnosis: Pterygium (1) Comment: Conjunctival tissue, usually on the nasal side, replaces the Bowman's membrane and drags vascularized conjunctiva on to the cornea. urlLink

Diagnosis: Conjunctivitis Lignosa Comment: Fast growing, gray to yellow tumor, of wooden consistency, no signs of inflammation. This is a rare form of recurring membranous conjunctivitis and may spontaneously resolve. The cause is unknown, occurs mostly in children. urlLink

Diagnosis: Lyell Syndrome, Drug Induced Erythema Multiforme Comment: Severe cicratrization of bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva with epidermization and vascularization of the cornea caused by Fansidar (sulfadoxine and pyrimethamine). urlLink
síndrome de Steven-Johnson urlLink

conjuntivite hiperaguda causada por Neisseria urlLink
conjuntivite bacteriana urlLink
conjuntivite aguda urlLink
